Comments_List: An intro to grant writing.

During this course, we were trained on how to critically think of science from a communication to an analytical range. We design a research aims page outlining our research project, goals and how we aimed to achieve them as part of our scientific training. Moreover, we participated of the mock of reviewers discussions to see how to address weaknesses within our grant applications to guarantee success.
Understand the basics of grant writing
I learned about current issues in ethics and research. These will help me consider the directions in which I take my research and the way I do it.
I learned about basic ethics and how to write a specific aims page.

I understand that covering research ethics is an NIH requirement and as such there may not be much flexibility in the curriculum, but I found many of these lectures exceedingly boring. Of course it is important to know and understand the history that led to the development of many important policies, but I think anyone who has ever been added to an IRB or worked with a model system has already learned these things, so I wish the lectures had been a little more dynamic since I don't think this material was new to many people. Furthermore, I know at other schools, the required research ethics course includes more discussion of scenarios we may encounter as graduate students/a workbook of scenarios so that you actually learn practical ways to handle tough situations.

Additionally, for the sexual harassment lecture, some (male) students commented that this lecture was unnecessary. I absolutely think it is necessary, but I don't think the woman who gave the lecture this year did a very good job, and honestly she did not inspire confidence in the way sexual harassment is handled at Yale.
I would say the strength of the course is how engaging and dynamic it was and the topics it covered. As for a weakness, I would say it was too late in the day.

Grant writing portion was very helpful. It could be even better by moving it to the end of the semester so we know what lab we will be in and our likely thesis project.
